<br>
Homicides over the last 12 months are trending <h8>`r ifelse(murders_city$inc_21tolast12>=0," up"," down")` `r ifelse(murders_city$inc_21tolast12>=0,murders_city$inc_21tolast12,substring(murders_city$inc_21tolast12,2))`%</h8> compared to 2021, according to the San Jose Police Department data through `r format(asofdate, "%B %d")`.

However, the murder rate over the last 12 months is <h8>`r case_when((murders_city$rate_last12-murders_city$rate_prior3years)>=0.25 ~ "up",(murders_city$rate_last12-murders_city$rate_prior3years)<=-0.25 ~ "down",TRUE ~ "about the same ")`</h8> compared to the annual average over the last three years.

<!-- The city averaged <h8>`r round(murders_city$last12mos/12,1)`</h8> homicides a month over the last 12 months. In 2019, that number was <h8>`r round(murders_city$total19/12,1)`</h8> a month. -->

One way to think about the danger: three years ago, the murder rate was <h8>`r murders_city$rate19`</h8> per 100,000 residents. That's far less than the risk of dying in a vehicle crash in California. The rate has fallen slightly to <h8>`r murders_city$rate_last12`</h8> in the last 12 months.

<br>

The risk is not the same neighborhood to neighborhood.

ABC7's data team looked at the San Jose Police Department's crime incident data by police district from 2019 through `r format(asofdate, "%B %d, %Y")`. Totals here include murders, but not involuntary manslaughter or justifiable homicide.

The San Jose Police Department does not release crime data broken down by more detailed neighborhoods or areas. The city police does release police reports and requests for service, but that data often includes calls or reports that are not equivalent to crimes. Therefore, this data is not reliable for showing the level of crime in local neighborhoods.
